Award.AwardTitle: Tailoring interface functionality of complex oxide heterostructures - A neutron and x-ray study
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract:
Complex transition-metal oxide heterostructures represent an emerging and rapidly growing field with both significant scientific merits and potential applications in spintronics, catalysts, solar cells, etc. A plethora of novel physical phenomena can arise at the interface of dissimilar materials in oxide heterostructures that are not attainable in the bulk constituents. This project investigates such novel phenomena in transition-metal oxide heterostructures via creation and manipulation of novel interface functionalities by tuning the substrate geometry and surface orientation. Importantly, this project serves as a platform to train the next-generation neutron and synchrotron x-ray scattering scientists, helping to promote the user community of the cutting-edge facilities in national laboratories. In addition to training graduate and undergraduate students, this project also supports the scientific research activities engaging high school teachers and K-12 students, as well as the activities of developing and presenting workshops to students in community colleges in Michigan.

Technical Abstract:
The project investigates the emergent quantum phenomena in correlated transition-metal oxide heterostructures via creation and manipulation of novel interface functionalities. Tuning the substrate geometry and surface orientation gives rise to diverse polar surface terminations, bond connections, and octahedral distortions, which are anticipated to affect electronic and orbital reconstruction as well as magnetic and structural coupling at the interfaces. Consequently, this can drastically alter physical properties of oxide heterostructures grown atop, providing a pathway to new physics and materials research. This project utilizes two unique and complementary techniques, i.e., polarized neutron reflectometry and polarized x-ray absorption spectroscopy, which offer high depth resolution and characteristic fingerprint of transition-metal elements to decisively determine the nature of interfacial magnetic and electronic states.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The condensed matter physics and materials science communities have witnessed the significant advances in the exploring new quantum materials and understanding the emergent phenomena in the past two decades, such as interfacial phenomenon in complex oxide heterostructures, discoveries of topological materials and Fe-based superconductors, etc. Furthermore, the functionalities of these materials hold promising applications in information storage and energy harvesting. The research supported by this grant investigated the interfacial electronic and magnetic properties of oxide heterostructures by tuning the substrate geometry, and explored the novel phenomena in correlated ruthenates with Ruddlesden-Popper layer structure via chemical substitution, magnetic field and electric field tuning. During the course of the project the scope was also expanded to study the interplay between magnetism and topological electronic states and to search for new topological states of quantum matter. The research work supported by this grant has led to 16 publications in peer-reviewed journals, many of which are highly ranked, including 1 in Physical Review Letter, 2 in Physical Review Research, 1 in Nature Scientific Report, and 9 in Physical Review B.

 

This project also offered great opportunities to integrate research and education activities. First, two Ph. D graduate students have been trained, who have become experts on neutron and x-ray scattering using the scattering facility infrastructure in national laboratories. Second, three undergraduate students have participated the research in the PI’s research laboratories, learning materials synthesis and characterization. Third, two senior high school students joined the group and performed research for seven weeks during the summer via the MSU High School Honors Science/Mathematics/Engineering program. It is worth noting that one of them co-authors a manuscript that is currently in preparation and that they both continued to pursue a science major in the undergraduate program.
